@Caitlin  You explanation of the rules of Pig Latin, while admirably concise, also sacrifices accuracy for concision.  It is not merely a matter of moving an initial consonant.  Were that the case, the word "that" would have to be rendered "hattay."  It's "atthay," though.  Same with "phone."  It's "onephay," not "honepay."  If the initial two consonants form a digraph, both consonants have to be moved to the end of the word.  At least that's how we spoke Pig Latin in my neck of the woods.

This already brought my thumbs up, but even more thumb lifting was Amsay‚Äôs creativity and skill in pulling off this theme.  Our language doesn‚Äôt provide many Pig Latin gimmees, like TRASH/ASHTRAY, and for most of these theme answers, he had to:
‚Ä¢	Invent Pig Latin pairs from sounds, such as TRON/ENTR√âE  and LOW/AU LAIT.
‚Ä¢	Find eight in-the-language phrases whose endings could be Pig-Latinned.
‚Ä¢	Have them fit symmetry, that is, come in four pairs, each with the same number of letters.
‚Ä¢	Have those theme answers be Sunday substantial (and they are), and design a quality grid to accommodate all eight.

AND....I circled the item at 83D on my Clue Page.  "Spin a yarn, perhaps?" has near-zero connection to CROCHET.  One may spin fibers and then weave, knit, tat, embroider, or crochet using the product, but there is a pretty big gap between spinning and working with what you've spun.  I did crochet with (actual) wool yarn before acrylics took over the Fiberverse, but long since moved on, though I still have my set of hooks.  My aunt, a talented weaver, learned to spin, and never touched a loom again.  This is a cautionary tale!  Sic semper weavers!

I have to recommend a game called Align that I've grown to love over the past few months.  It's in the Boston Globe, and it's free (just Google Boston Globe games).  It's simple to play, and comes with a short tutorial.

It's quick -- usually under four minutes and often under two -- and it uses and hones crosswords skills.  And it's a heck of a lot of fun.

One of its creators is Brendan Emmet Quigley, a name crossword fans will recognize.

@Tom translating the last word in pig Latin changes the meaning of a common phrase to match the clue, for example "Not your average Joe" changes to "Not your average O-Jay (OJ)", aka a good breakfast drink. If you clock this pattern part way through you *can* use it to help solve some of the themed clues if you have worked out the common phrase it's spinning off, I got "to ebay or not to ebay" and "toss in the ashtray" this way. @Ms. Billie M. Spaight

"pig latin":  For words starting with consonants or Y, put the first letter of the word at its end, and then add ay. For words beginning with A, E, I, O or U, "way" is added as an ending.

So, "au" being prounounced "oh", put that after lait  which is prounounced "lay", but  take away the "ay" and you L + "oh", or "low".
